description: DHCP Service fixer offline from rescue VM
Enables serial access console offline from a rescue VM on GEN1 and GEN2 windows VMs
Enables serial access console offline from a rescue VM on GEN1 and GEN2 windows VMs and enables os dump collector as well on main OS drive
Last Known Good Configuration enabler offline from rescue VM
Fixes integrity of files and registry from windows guest agent offline
Hello world test script
Hello world test script
Error test script
Error test script
Runs chkdsk to fix file system corruption
Runs sfc to fix system file corruption
Ignore errors if there is a failed boot, failed shutdown, or failed checkpoint. The computer will attempt to boot normally after an error occurs.
This ID is deprectated. Please use 'linux-alar2' instead. For backward compatibility it will use the linux-alar2 ID automatically.

alar2 allows to recover a failed VM. Various ations are available like: fstab, initrd and kernel. NOTE: use option --run-on-repair. See the docu for more details: https://github.com/Azure/repair-script-library/blob/master/src/linux/common/helpers/alar2/README.md. The script takes around 2min to run.
Enables nested hyperV using attached data disk as OS disk.
Disable Safe Mode if your Windows VM is booting in Safe Mode. Also activates Safe Mode if you require it (e.g. to uninstall certain software).
Changes the dump configuration of a VM while its running without the need to reboot it. Which is to say, you can change the dump configuration from Kernel to Full without a reboot.
Collect OS logs from an OS disk attached to a Rescue VM as an Azure Data Disk.
Create a new user account with administrator privileges. This can be used to troubleshoot a VM without an accessible administrative account.
Get installed Windows patches for the nested Hyper-V server on a Rescue VM using DISM.

Remove an installed Windows patch for the nested Hyper-V server on a Rescue VM using DISM. This will be helpful if the attached OS disk is from a VM that is in a nonboot state due to corrupted/failing updates.
Get Windows applications for the nested Hyper-V machine that can be uninstalled from the Rescue VM.
Remove an installed Windows application from the nested Hyper-V machine.
Modify the registry on an OS disk attached to a Rescue VM as an Azure Data Disk.
